title: 110_hr1618
content: Section 1 introduces a new tax credit for plug-in hybrid vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A new tax credit is introduced for plug-in hybrid vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for 10% of the cost of a qualified plug-in hybrid vehicle to be deducted from the taxpayer's tax liability. There are limitations on the credit amount per vehicle, with a maximum of $4,000 for a plug-in electric drive vehicle with a 4kWh traction battery, and an additional $250 for each kWh of battery capacity exceeding 4kWh but not exceeding 50kWh. The credit can be applied along with other business credits. The tax credit for plug-in hybrid vehicles allows for a deduction of 10% of the vehicle cost from the taxpayer's tax liability. There are limitations on the credit amount per vehicle, with a maximum of $4,000 for a plug-in electric drive vehicle with a 4kWh traction battery, and an additional $250 for each kWh of battery capacity exceeding 4kWh but not exceeding 50kWh. The credit can be applied along with other business credits. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall not exceed the sum of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under subpart A and subpart B. The term 'qualified plug-in hybrid vehicle' refers to a motor vehicle meeting specific criteria, including being acquired for personal use, made by a manufacturer, having a certificate of conformity under the Clean Air Act, and having at least 2 different onboard energy sources for propulsion. The term 'qualified plug-in hybrid vehicle' includes vehicles with at least one source energized by an external electric power source and another source energized by an internal combustion engine or fuel cell for mechanical propulsion. This term excludes vehicles that are not passenger automobiles or light trucks with a gross vehicle weight rating of less than 8,500 pounds. The term 'kWh traction battery capacity' refers to the size of an electrochemical storage device in kWh, measured from 100% to 0% state of charge. Special rules include reducing the basis of property by the amount of the credit and regulations for recapturing the credit benefit if the property ceases. No credit allowed for property outside the US or if a double benefit is received from another provision. Taxpayer can elect not to take credit for a vehicle. The section discusses rules for property used by tax-exempt entities and the termination of the section after December 31, 2014. It also excludes plug-in hybrid vehicles from the limitation on new qualified hybrid vehicles eligible for the credit. Additionally, the credit is now part of the general business credit. The amendment adds a new paragraph related to the plug-in hybrid vehicle credit and makes a conforming amendment to the tax code. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
